content: The House and Senate approved FY1999 defense bills, with additional funding of $8.3 billion for various defense-related purposes. The President signed both bills into law on October 17. The FY1999 defense appropriations bill allocated funds for various defense-related purposes, including fixes in the Defense Department, storm damage repairs, purchasing fissile materials from Russia, antiterrorism activities, and defense counter-drug activities. The bill, signed into law on October 21 (P.L. 105-277), primarily funds military activities of the Department of Defense, weapons procurement, and research and development. Additionally, it provides funding for the Central Intelligence Agency retirement fund and intelligence community management, as well as classified amounts for national foreign intelligence activities. The FY1999 defense appropriations bill allocated funds for various defense-related purposes, including fixes in the Defense Department, storm damage repairs, purchasing fissile materials from Russia, antiterrorism activities, and defense counter-drug activities. The Administration's budget included $270.6 billion for national defense, with $250.8 billion requested in the defense appropriations bill. Congress also acts on a national defense authorization bill annually, addressing defense programs in detail. The debate over defense policy and funding issues mainly occurs during action on the authorization bill. Congress completed action on the annual defense authorization and appropriations bills on October 1. The House and Senate allocated funds for defense programs on May 14 and June 16 respectively, which determine the available funding for defense and other programs. The final Senate allocations for defense subcommittee are slightly below the Administration's request, with $250.290 billion in budget authority and $244.942 billion in outlays. The House allocations provide $250.499 billion in budget authority and $244.965 billion in outlays for the national security subcommittee. The House approved the FY1999 defense authorization bill, H.R. 3616, on May 6. The FY1999 defense authorization bill, H.R. 3616, was approved by the House on May 21. The Senate passed their version of the bill, S. 2057, on June 25. Conferees reached agreement on the authorization bill on September 17, and it was signed into law as P.L. 105-261 on October 17. The House also passed the FY1999 defense appropriations bill, H.R. 4103, on June 24. The Senate passed the FY1999 defense appropriations bill, S. 2132, on July 30, which was later signed into law as P.L. 105-262 on October 17. The House approved H.Con.Res. 284 for the annual congressional budget resolution on June 5, but a conference agreement was never completed. Supplemental defense appropriations for FY1998 were approved for military operations in Bosnia and Southwest Asia, domestic and defense disaster relief, totaling $2.7 billion for the Defense Department. In FY1998, supplemental defense appropriations were approved for military operations in Bosnia and Southwest Asia, domestic and defense disaster relief, totaling $2.7 billion. In FY1999, an omnibus appropriations bill (H.R. 4328) provided additional defense-related funding of $8.3 billion, including allocations for Bosnia operations, military readiness, intelligence, missile defense, year 2000 fixes, storm damage repairs, defense health program, purchase of fissile materials from Russia, defense antiterrorism activities, and defense counter-drug efforts. The omnibus appropriations bill for FY1999 allocated $8.3 billion for defense-related funding, including funds for Bosnia operations, military readiness, intelligence, missile defense, year 2000 fixes, storm damage repairs, defense health program, purchase of fissile materials from Russia, defense antiterrorism activities, and defense counter-drug efforts. The bill also included emergency appropriations for various defense activities and made rescissions of $67 million. The conference agreements on the defense authorization and appropriations bills resolved issues related to relations with China, particularly regarding satellite and missile technology exports. The Senate-passed bill included contentious China-related provisions in the authorization conference. The agreement dropped language banning satellite exports to China but included measures transferring technology export review to the State Department, requiring congressional notification for satellite sales to China, and prohibiting missile equipment exports unless certified not to harm the U.S. space launch industry or enhance China's missile capabilities. The appropriations conference agreement includes measures prohibiting the transfer of port facilities near San Diego to a Chinese shipping company and a prohibition on DOD doing business with Chinese Army-owned companies. It also requires a report on the security situation in the Taiwan Strait and does not approve new rounds of military base closures. The Senate approved an amendment to make it more difficult for the Defense Department to realign military bases without a base closure process. DOD objected but the provision was dropped in the conference agreement. The House bill required separation of men and women in basic training, while the Senate bill prohibited new policies until a commission reports. The Senate endorsed a substitute by Senator Snowe allowing current integrated training practices to continue with additional steps for separate sleeping quarters. The House-Senate conference adopted the Senate language with a "sense of the House" statement urging separate training units. The conference agreement included a provision for commanders to display "exemplary behavior" as a statement. Both the House and Senate rejected amendments to lift the ban on abortions in military medical facilities. The House-passed bill included a measure on tritium production. The House-passed bill included a measure on tritium production, which would prohibit the DOE from buying tritium from commercial nuclear reactors. The cost of buying tritium from commercial sources over the next forty years is estimated at $3 billion, while building new facilities in South Carolina would cost $10 billion. The Senate version allows DOE to choose the long-term option, but implementation is prohibited for a year for Congress to review the decision. The House also rejected an Administration request to eliminate floors on active duty end-strength levels. The House-passed bill included a measure on tritium production, prohibiting the DOE from buying tritium from commercial nuclear reactors. The Senate version allows DOE to choose the long-term option, but implementation is prohibited for a year for Congress to review the decision. The House also rejected an Administration request to eliminate floors on active duty end-strength levels. The Senate and House versions of the appropriations bill agreed to the Administration's proposed reductions in end-strength levels. The authorization conference report agreed to the Administration's request. The House initially provided a pay raise of 3.6% for military personnel, while the Senate and both House and Senate versions of the appropriations bill initially provided only the requested raise of 3.1%. However, an amendment was approved to increase the pay raise to 3.6%, offset by a reduction in R&D funds. The authorization and appropriations conference agreements ultimately provided a 3.6% raise. The Administration requested $1.9 billion for Bosnia in FY1999 as emergency funding not subject to the cap on defense spending. The Senate approved the funding, while the House did not. The Senate version stipulated the funding as emergency appropriations, while the House capped Bosnia spending at $1.9 billion. Both houses rejected measures to withdraw U.S. troops from Bosnia by a specific date. The authorization conference agreement authorizes $1.9 billion in emergency funding for Bosnia, with the possibility of larger expenditures if certified necessary for national security. The appropriations conference agreement did not include emergency funding but was later provided in a supplemental appropriations measure. Weapons priorities were less contentious this year, with the Administration requesting one C-130J aircraft and objecting to additional funding for 7 more aircraft in the House authorization. The House and Senate authorization and appropriations bills allocated funds for 7 additional aircraft, exceeding the requested amount. Funding for the THAAD system was reduced after a test failure in May, with the authorization conference agreement cutting $294 million and the appropriations conference agreement cutting $376 million. The Senate bills also reduced or eliminated funding for the MEADS system, a cooperative program with allies that the Administration wants to continue. The authorization conference agreement cuts funding for the MEADS system from $44 million to $24 million and requires Defense Department approval for future budget plans. The appropriations conference agreement only provides $10 million. Funding for the Airborne Laser program was reduced while Space-Based Laser R&D received an increase. Both House and Senate appropriations bills also decreased funding for new aircraft carrier development due to the Navy's decision not to pursue a new design. The authorization conference agreement provides $110 million and the appropriations conference agreement provides $105 million of the $190 million requested for developing progressive changes in the current design. Funds were allocated for a new LHD-8 amphibious ship and 30 F-18s, as requested. There were disagreements on the procurement of new F/A-18E/F aircraft and the addition of funds for unrequested F-16 aircraft. The Administration objected to a requirement in the Senate authorization bill regarding testing for the F-22 aircraft before additional procurement contracts are signed. The authorization conference agreement includes restrictions that can be waived, with some cuts in certain programs to finance increases in others. Long-term weapons issues seem to have been resolved, with the battle over B-2 bomber procurement and design competition in the New Attack Submarine program settled. Both House and Senate bills aim to ensure military retirees have access to the defense health care system. The authorization conference agreement includes pilot projects to test alternative approaches for military retirees' access to healthcare, such as joining the Federal Employees Health Benefit Plan (FEHBP) and using TRICARE as a supplement for Medicare. Other key matters discussed in the defense debate included military base closures, Bosnia funding, technology export controls, efficiency measures, and military readiness. The Administration's request for FY1999 defense spending was at the agreed level of $270.5 billion, leading to discussions on major weapons programs, military personnel levels, National Guard funding, and other defense-related matters. The defense debate in Congress for the FY1999 budget involved a "zero-sum game" where any additional funds added for favored programs had to be offset by reductions in other defense programs. Congress ultimately provided an extra $8.3 billion for defense programs in the omnibus appropriations bill. This budget constraint could have led to a confrontation between Congress and the Administration over defense priorities. Senior Administration officials tried to avoid conflicts by compromising with Congress on ongoing programs of interest. They fully funded national missile defense development, increased funding for National Guard and Reserve equipment, covered all defense health program costs, and accelerated funding for the next Nimitz-class aircraft carrier. The House and Senate did not engage in a contentious debate over defense budget priorities in the FY1999 bills, with only small amounts allocated for unrequested weapons programs. The FY1999 defense budget priorities were influenced by the Quadrennial Defense Review, Defense Reform Initiative report, and National Defense Panel report. The QDR reassessed U.S. defense policy, the DRI report identified efficiency measures, and the NDP report focused on future defense requirements. These reports will continue to shape congressional discussions. The Quadrennial Defense Review (QDR) proposed a revised U.S. defense strategy, emphasized the need for efficiency to save money for weapons modernization, and endorsed military base closures. The National Defense Panel report supported the QDR's focus on shaping the international security environment but called for greater emphasis on homeland defense. The National Defense Panel recommended a shift in focus towards homeland defense and preparing for future threats, calling for increased spending on experimental force exercises and new technology. It also supported two more rounds of military base closures to save money for defense modernization programs. Congress was not initially receptive to the proposal, but Secretary Cohen pushed for approval of two new base closure rounds in 2001 and 2005. The Defense Department released a report on base closures, reaffirming previous estimates of annual savings. Two future base closure rounds are projected to save $2.8 billion each. Resistance in Congress stems from objections to actions following the 1995 base closure round. The 1995 Base Closure Commission recommended closing two Air Force maintenance facilities in California and Texas, but the White House opted for privatization instead. This decision sparked controversy in Congress over politicizing the base closure process. Lawmakers criticized an Air Force memo discussing a White House request for the Defense Department to encourage a private company to bid on a contract for work at the Sacramento facility. Secretary Cohen faced complaints in congressional hearings about privatization eroding support for base closures. Cohen suggested Congress could prohibit privatization in future base closure legislation and advocated for more base closures to be approved in preparation for the long-term defense plan. An amendment by Senator Inhofe aimed to make it harder for DOD to realign facilities without a congressionally established base closure process. However, Senator Inhofe predicted that Congress would approve another base closure round for 2001. The amendment was ultimately dropped by the authorization conference.
